turns.speaker: SECRET SERVICE MAN
turns.text: Look, um, if you give me your name and address, we'll send you the information on how to apply.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: You would, huh?

turns.speaker: SECRET SERVICE MAN
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: My name is Henry Krinkle -- that's with a "K." K-R-I-N-K-L-E. I live at 13 1/2 Hopper Avenue, Fair Lawn, New Jersey. Zip code 07410.  Got that?

turns.speaker: SECRET SERVICE MAN
turns.text: Sure, Henry. I got it all. We'll send you all the stuff all right.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Great, hey. Thanks a lot.

turns.speaker: SPORT
turns.text: Here, officer, take me in. I'm clean. I didn't do it. Got a ticket once in Jersey. That's all. Honest, officer.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Your name Sport?

turns.speaker: SPORT
turns.text: Anything you say, officer.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I'm no cop.  I want some action.

turns.speaker: SPORT
turns.text: I saw. $20 fifteen minutes. $30 half hour.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Shit.

turns.speaker: SPORT
turns.text: Take it or leave it.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I'm no cop.

turns.speaker: SPORT
turns.text: Well, if you are, it's entrapment already.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I'm hip.

turns.speaker: SPORT
turns.text: Funny, you don't look hip.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Hey, Sport. How are things?

turns.speaker: SPORT
turns.text: O.K., cowboy.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: How are things in the pimp business, hey Sport?

turns.speaker: SPORT
turns.text: What's going on?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I'm here to see Iris.

turns.speaker: SPORT
turns.text: Iris?

turns.speaker: SPORT
turns.text: Wha -- ?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Yeah, Iris. You know anybody by that name?

turns.speaker: SPORT
turns.text: No.  Hillbilly, you'd better get your wise ass outa here and quick, or you're gonna be in trouble.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Get it.

turns.speaker: SPORT
turns.text: Hey, mister, I don't know what's going on here. This don't make any sense.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Show it to me.

turns.speaker: WIZARD
turns.text: Travis.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Hey Wizard.

turns.speaker: WIZARD
turns.text: So howsit?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Some fleet driver for Bell just got cut up. Just heard it on the radio.

turns.speaker: WIZARD
turns.text: What's the action around?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Slow.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Wiz?

turns.speaker: WIZARD
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Look, ah, we never talked much, you and me...

turns.speaker: WIZARD
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I wanted to ask you something, on account you've been around so long.

turns.speaker: WIZARD
turns.text: Shoot. They don't call me the Wizard for nothing.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Well, I just, you know...

turns.speaker: WIZARD
turns.text: Things got ya down?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Real down.

turns.speaker: WIZARD
turns.text: It happens.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Sometimes it gets so I just don't know what I'm gonna do. I get some real crazy ideas, you know? Just go out and do somethin.

turns.speaker: WIZARD
turns.text: The taxi life, you mean.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: WIZARD
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Like do anything, you know.

turns.speaker: WIZARD
turns.text: Travis, look, I dig it. Let me explain. You choose a certain way of life. You live it. It becomes what you are. I've been a hack 27 years, the last ten at night. Still don't own my own cab. I guess that's the way I want it.  You see, that must be what I am.

turns.speaker: WIZARD
turns.text: Look, a person does a certain thing and that's all there is to it. It becomes what he is. Why fight it? What do you know? How long you been a hack, a couple months? You're like a peg and you get dropped into a slot and you got to squirm and wiggle around a while until you fit in.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: That's just about the dumbest thing I ever heard, Wizard.

turns.speaker: WIZARD
turns.text: What do you expect, Bertrand Russell? I've been a cabbie all my life, what do I know?  I don't even know what you're talking about.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Neither do I, I guess.

turns.speaker: WIZARD
turns.text: You fit in. It's lonely, it's rough at first. But you fit in. You got no choice.

turns.speaker: WIZARD
turns.text: Yeah. Sorry, Wizard.

turns.speaker: WIZARD
turns.text: Don't worry, Killer. You'll be all right.  I seen enough to know.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: Had a close one.

turns.speaker: CARLA
turns.text: You want to talk about it?

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: Not really.

turns.speaker: CARLA
turns.text: You know how I feel about what you do.

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: Could we change the subject?

turns.speaker: CARLA
turns.text: That record company.in Nashville wants to hear my demo tape.

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: Hey!  Now there's some good news.

turns.speaker: CARLA
turns.text: You think I'm too...  ethnic for country music?

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: Carla Pestalozzi?  No. Definitely not.  You could have posed for the Mona= Lisa.  Sophia Loren looks Swedish next to you.

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: Stick with Carla.

turns.speaker: CARLA
turns.text: Okay.  How 'bout Carla Goodspeed?  Six years, Bill.  We've lived together six years.

turns.speaker: CARLA
turns.text: Don't stop...  do no stop.

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: Shit, shit, shit what time is it.  Hello.  I'll be downstairs in ten minutes.

turns.speaker: SANCHEZ
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: Ancient Greece.  Alchimadus was imprisoned by his king.

turns.speaker: SANCHEZ
turns.text: Maybe.  Not really.

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: Archbishop of Canterbury.  Imprisoned and executed by Henry the Second ...

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: SANCHEZ
turns.text: You're not wimping out on us, Goodspeed.

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: I join the F.B.I. I ask for fieldwork.  They say, "Bill, you're too fucking= smart for field work." Every year I put in for a transfer and every year I= sit in that goddamn lab like the fucking Maytag repairman in the= commercial.  Then the call finally comes, and it's a whole fuckin, city at= stake?  Oh Jesus...

turns.speaker: SANCHEZ
turns.text: Spit it out.

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: MY girlfriend's pregnant.

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: It's me sir.

turns.speaker: SANCHEZ
turns.text: What is happening?  Where's Mason?

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: He says he's leaving the island sir.

turns.speaker: SANCHEZ
turns.text: Don't let him do that.

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: He's got a gun, sir.

turns.speaker: SANCHEZ
turns.text: What do you have, a FUCKING WATER PISTOL?  Get him back!

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: Just come and get me, sir.  I'm tired.

turns.speaker: SANCHEZ
turns.text: Name your vacation spot, Goodspeed. The Bureau'll pay for it.

turns.speaker: MASON
turns.text: What do you do for the F.B.I., Goodspeed.

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: I'm a field agent.

turns.speaker: MASON
turns.text: Tell me what you really do.

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: I don't understand....

turns.speaker: MASON
turns.text: During the time I cooperate, will I be outside?  Outside a jail?

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: Well yes I suppose ...

turns.speaker: MASON
turns.text: You suppose?

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: Yes.  You'll be outside.

turns.speaker: MASON
turns.text: John Mason.  ' Don't be shocked.  I don't have much time.  Please listen carefully  ....

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: Where is he sir?  RIGHT IN FRONT OF ME.  What's he doing?  HE'S ON THE= PHONE.  I DON'T FUCKING KNOW, HIS STOCKBROKER! Oh shit.  Gotta go.

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: Motor oil?

turns.speaker: MASON
turns.text: For cottonmouth. Goodspeed and the S.E.A.L.s exchange looks.

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: Don't shoot me. Mason was actually slinging it over his shoulder...

turns.speaker: MASON
turns.text: For christ's sake. Mason trudges down the tu=3Del.  Goodspeed follows him.

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: Wait.  Where're you going?

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: I.don't get it.  You're going to help me?

turns.speaker: MASON
turns.text: No. I'm going to give you dancing lessons.  What the fuck do you think?

turns.speaker: MASON
turns.text: Limp dick?

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: It's all I could think of.

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: I'll go.

turns.speaker: MASON
turns.text: Wrong.

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: What, vou?

turns.speaker: MASON
turns.text: I'm not the chemical weapons expert.

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: MASON
turns.text: Now they only have three rockets left.

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: Wait.

turns.speaker: MASON
turns.text: Find the rockets.  If they're guarded, kill the men guarding them.

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: Mason.  Mason?

turns.speaker: MASON
turns.text: It's about time.

turns.speaker: MASON
turns.text: You referring to your intellect, Goodspeed?  Or another portion of your= anatomy ....

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: The cell, Mason.

turns.speaker: MASON
turns.text: Surprise, surprise.

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: I'm not a field agent, all right?  So cut me a break.

turns.speaker: MASON
turns.text: An F.B.I. Man asking me for a break. How droll.

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: Partners?

turns.speaker: MASON
turns.text: Partners.

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: Mason, uhm, John, I have something to tell you.  You know that pardon= contract you signed?

turns.speaker: MASON
turns.text: Womack ripped it up, right?

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: You knew?  All this time?

turns.speaker: MASON
turns.text: I'm not a fool, Billy.

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: All I know is that whatever you did, you don't deserve to go back.

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: God's speed.

turns.speaker: MASON
turns.text: Yes.  To wish someone a prosperous jouey.

turns.speaker: MASON
turns.text: St. Michael's Church, Fort Walton, Kansas.  Front pew.  Right leg. = Hollow.

turns.speaker: GOODSPEED
turns.text: What's that?  Mason?

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: I'm sure a lot of people down in L.A. are worried sick about you.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Yeah?  I'm sure a lot more people down in L.A. want a piece of me.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: This Luke was a pretty good guy, wasn't he?

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Oh, yes.  Yes, he was.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Well... let me tell you, I'm not Luke.  I know who I am now, and you don't.  And... I don't like me very much.

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: You know, it's going to take me a while to get used to calling you Pete.  Pete.  Pete.  It's a nice name.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Thanks, I like it.  I think.

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: I believe you.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: The truth is, I'm a lot of things, but communist isn't one of them.

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: But if you only went to one meeting, why does anyone care? Besides, why should it even matter if you were a communist?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Come on, Delly, look at the country today.  We're fighting communists in Korea, we're paranoid about the Russians, we've got this thing with the Rosenbergs and the atomic bomb...  You think they want "suspected communists" entertaining the American public with party propaganda like, gosh I don't know, "Sand Pirates of the Sahara?"

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Forget about all that.  You want to do the right thing?  Then defend your name.  If someone says something about you that's untrue, you have to stand up and say so.  I know the law, and the law's on your side.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: What about you, Delly?

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: I am, too.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: You'll stand by me?

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Whatever happens.

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: You've got everything?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Yeah.  Except a chance in hell of coming out of this intact.

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: You'll be fine.  No matter what Leo Kubelsky says, you've got a hundred and seventy-five years of American law on your side.  Don't forget that.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: I wish you were coming with me.

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: And who's gonna run the projector until you get back?  Mrs. Terwilliger?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Maybe we could train Cat to run the projector.  You know, a system of scratching posts, and gears, and levers...

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Did you bring along something to read?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Damn...

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Not exactly light reading, I know. Believe it or not, I've read this since high school, and it got me all the way through law school. Besides, there's something in there that'll help you.  You won't have to get very far, it's near the beginning.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Delly... thanks, thank you.  I'll take good care of this.

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Just remember two things.  First, the law is a living thing.  It made us free and it keeps us free. Sometimes it gets twisted around by people for their own purposes. Sometimes it makes mistakes, sometimes big mistakes.  But in the end, the law prevails for the just. Sometimes, it takes a while.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Okay.  What's the second thing?

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Tell them Pete.  Tell them...

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Mr. Chairman, as I understand it, the Fifth Amendment pertains to self-incrimination, and I can't incriminate myself because I've done nothing wrong.  Besides, incrimination is why you have Mr. Clyde working for you.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: I see you got the telegram.

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Pete, I'm so sorry about what they did to you.  I didn't think you'd come back, I thought you'd want to write again...

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Dell, I can't write unless I'm happy, and I can't be happy unless I'm here -- and with you.  This is me, Delly.  Pete Appleton. And I love you!

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: And  I love you, Pete!

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Dad?

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: Delly?  In here.

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: How'd it go?

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Not as bad as I thought it would. I think I passed.

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: That's my girl!  Did you...?

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: No hiccups, which was good.  Who wants an attorney who gets the hiccups when she gets nervous?  "Your  honor, I  object!"

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: I think  it's worse  now.

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: That always used to work.

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Yeah, well it's not everyday you get  news like this.  You're sure he's  okay?  Other than the  bump on the head?

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: Well...

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Dad...

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: He doesn't remember anything, Delly.  Doesn't know how he got here, doesn't remember his father, the town, the Bijou, anyone...

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: ... including me.  Right?

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: I'm afraid not.  He looked right at your picture without batting an eye.  But it's probably temporary. He got all the way to Lawson, so he clearly knew who he was and what he was doing until he hit his head. I'm sure it'll all come back to him.  It just takes a catalyst.

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: You mean,  me?

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: It's possible.

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Daddy, that's Luke, can you let him in?  I'll be right down.

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: Honey, I... I can't... it's the...

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Besides, Daddy's still trying to figure out how to get his new television set working.

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: I had it, a minute ago...

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Do you... remember me?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: I've seen you before.  Your picture...

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: What.

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: No, I... I just wondering where you've been all this time.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Me too.

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: You look... different.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: I do?

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Yeah, a little.  I think you grew an inch or so.  And you've lost weight.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: I did?  Huh!

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: You can all go home, now.  He's not going anywhere.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Go on home, folks.  And thanks for the welcome.

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Then why do I feel like we're still being shadowed?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Well... where can we go?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: City hall?

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: You must not remember anything. Come on.

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: You first.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Why me?

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Be a gentleman.  You have to help me down.

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Of course, there was a lot more room before they stuck the memorial down here.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: How'd they get it inside?

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Through the door.  It comes apart.

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Right here.  "Albert Lucas Trumbo." And all the others.  I knew them all.  So did you.  We went to school with most of them.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: It doesn't seem right, this being down here.  It ought to be where people can see it.

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: After they commissioned it, no one could ever agree on where to put it.  The Methodists wanted it in front of the Methodist Church, the Presbyterians wanted it in front of the Presbyterian Church, the city council wanted it in the lobby of City Hall.  Everyone finally got tired of the fighting.  So they stuck it down here.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: So, you're really gonna be a lawyer?

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: And why not?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Whoa.

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Sorry.  You don't know how many times I've heard that.  "A lady lawyer?  Are you crazy?"  Like a woman couldn't be as good a lawyer as a man.  Or better, in fact.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Have you always wanted to be a lawyer?

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: You... don't remember, but yes, ever since I was a little girl.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: What did... what did I want to be?

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Oh, well... I guess you... in high school, you were a pretty good first baseman.  And we were on the debate team together.  But... I think you were gonna run the Bijou. You were brought up there, and you loved it so much.  And I think you knew how much the town needed a place like that.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: You don't have a boyfriend or anyone... you know... like that?

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Actually, I was married.  For four years.  But... well, we didn't fit together.  I'm divorced now.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: No, it's okay.  See, when two people belong together, the other person should be the... the key that unlocks the rest of you... I'm not making sense, am I?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: No, you are.  I know exactly what you mean.  It's not that you're missing something.  It's that the other person gives something to you... that you had all the time. You just didn't see it until they came along.

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Yeah...

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: We were in love... weren't we?

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Yes.  Hic!

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: What was that?

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Do you have the...

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: I'm  fine.  Really.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Were we going to get married?

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Eventually.  We were going to be  engaged... when you came back from  overseas...

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: No... you were wearing that suit the last time we went out before...

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Oh...

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: ... and It's just... well, deja vu.

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: This is strange.  Do you feel it?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: We've done this before, so many times.  The last time was so long ago, but it feels like yesterday.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: You know, everyone's so excited about the Bijou re-opening...

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: It's gonna cost over nine hundred dollars to open the place, Delly.

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Nine hundred...

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Yeah, and needless to say, none of us has that kind of money lying around.

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: What about a loan?  You could go to the bank...?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: A loan to a man who ran his business into the ground and his son who can't account for the last nine-and-a-half years of his life? Not likely.

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Well, there's got to be a way...

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Have you got a cigarette?

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: When did you start smoking?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: I don't smoke?

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: You tried to once.  It was pretty pitiful.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: They're not bad.

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: No, they're not.  I'd say your investment was paying dividends.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: My what?

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Back in '37, you heard Benny Goodman play for the first time, so you went out and got a used clarinet.  You wanted nothing more than to be able to play like him. You tried hard, but it wasn't long before it was clear that Benny Goodman would never be looking over his shoulder.  So you gave the clarinet to Spencer.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Huh.  That was nice of me.

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: You had a hidden agenda, though. See, when he was five or six, little Spence used to follow you around like a puppy.  Bothered the hell out of you.  But as soon as you gave him the clarinet...

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: ... he started practicing, and he left me alone from then on.

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Exactly.  And he got good.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: No kidding.

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Now, did you remember that, or...

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Nope.  Just filling in the blanks.

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Oh.  Okay.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: How do you tell those two apart, anyway?

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Alex and Charlie?  Simple.  Alex is the smarter one.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: That's... pretty frightening.

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: Your dancing's very good.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: It never used to be.  You were two left feet on the dance floor.  Like pulling teeth to get you to do a little box step.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Guess I must've learned.

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: What... do you remember?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Well... everything.  It started coming back a couple of days ago. I remember everything now.

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: I see...

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Delly.  I'm... I'm not... Harry wasn't my father.  And I'm not... I'm not Luke.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Delly, shhhhhh...

turns.speaker: ADELE
turns.text: No... I can't... I have to... I can't...

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Sir, that is true.

turns.speaker: CLYDE
turns.text: Mr. Appleton, do you know an "Albert Lucas Trumbo?"

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Luke Trumbo?  We never met.  But I'd like to think I know him.

turns.speaker: CLYDE
turns.text: Is that because you were masquerading as Luke Trumbo while you were in Lawson?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Mr. Clyde you're twisting things around.  I wasn't masquerading. Luke Trumbo... Luke was a good man who gave his life for his country. I just... happen to look a little bit like him.  That's all.

turns.speaker: CLYDE
turns.text: Yes, I see that Private Trumbo was reported missing in action and is presumed dead.  I also see that you were posted stateside during the war.  Fort Dix?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: CLYDE
turns.text: Well, I'm sure we're all glad to see you came through it all right.

turns.speaker: CLYDE
turns.text: Now, I see that you've been running a movie theater in Lawson called "The Bijou," is that also true?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Yes sir.  But I didn't go to Lawson to run The Bijou, that was... that was something that just happened. You see, I was involved in an accident in Lawson, and I spent some time recovering there.

turns.speaker: CLYDE
turns.text: Anyone who reads the newspaper is quite familiar with your... "accident," Mr. Appleton.  An accident which, conveniently, came hard upon your dismissal from United Pictures.  Tell us, this "accident" of yours, are we given to understand that it affected your memory?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: CLYDE
turns.text: And what is the state of your memory now?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Sir, are you referring to the fact that I was suffering from amnesia, and I've since recovered my memory?

turns.speaker: CLYDE
turns.text: I'm interested in knowing if you remember things you did in your past, or if they've been conveniently "blotted out" as a result of your "accident."

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Mr. Clyde, I remember everything.

turns.speaker: CLYDE
turns.text: Good.  Good.  Now, I hold in my hand a photostatic copy of the attendance roster for the "Bread Instead of Bullets Club" of the University of California, Los Angeles, dated October 11, 1935.  A copy of this paper is before you, Mr. Appleton. Do you recognize it?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Yes... yes, I do.

turns.speaker: CLYDE
turns.text: Referring to line thirty-seven of the document, does your printed name and signature appear there?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Yes it does.

turns.speaker: CLYDE
turns.text: Mr. Appleton, please tell this committee what was the nature and purpose of the "Bread Instead of Bullets Club?"

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Mr. Clyde, do you want to know what I knew then, or do you want to know what I know now?  They're two different things?

turns.speaker: CLYDE
turns.text: Start with what you knew then.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Well, I'd direct the attention of counsel and committee to line thirty-six of the document, and the name printed and signed there.

turns.speaker: CLYDE
turns.text: We see it.  For the record, it reads "Lucille Angstrom."  What's the point of this?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Well, that's what I knew then.  Or who I knew, I should say.  You see, I was trying to court Miss Angstrom.  I went to the meeting to impress her.

turns.speaker: CLYDE
turns.text: Are you asking this committee to believe that you attended a meeting of a communist party front organization in order to impress a girl?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Well, if you'd seen Miss Angstrom...

turns.speaker: CLYDE
turns.text: All right, Mr. Appleton.  That was what you knew then.  What do you know now?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Well, I know that I lost my job because of one meeting I went to when I was a kid in college.  I know that I've been branded a communist, which I'm not, but even if I was, it shouldn't matter, or what do we have a Bill Of Rights for?

turns.speaker: CLYDE
turns.text: Mr. Chairman, the witness is being non-responsive...

turns.speaker: CLYDE
turns.text: Are you now, or have you ever been, a member of the communist party?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: No, sir.

turns.speaker: CLYDE
turns.text: Are you refuting this evidence and your previous testimony?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: I'm not refuting anything.

turns.speaker: CLYDE
turns.text: Yet you're contradicting yourself. You earlier testified that you attended a meeting of a communist party-run organization, yet you just said, under oath, that you were not now -- nor ever -- a member of the communist party.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: That's not a contradiction at all, sir.  I went to the meeting, but I didn't go as a member.

turns.speaker: CLYDE
turns.text: Well, then, as what did you go?

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Do you swear that the testimony you are about to give before this committee of the United States House of Representatives will be the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth, so help you god?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: I do.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Be seated and state your full name and place of residence for the record.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Peter Kenneth Appleton.  Hollywood, California.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: The chair notes that you are appearing without the benefit of counsel today, Mr. Appleton.  We certainly hope this means that you intend to be fully forthcoming with this committee?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: I'll do my best, Mr. Chairman.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Now, we're informed that you have a statement you'd like to read, is that correct?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: A statement?

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Yes.  A prepared statement.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Um... no.  I don't have a statement at this time.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: I'm a little hesitant to say.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: The witness need not be hesitant to say anything before this committee, as long as it's the truth.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Mr. Appleton, you are making light of a legally constituted committee of the United States Congress. Believe you me, you do not want to incur our wrath.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: I'm sorry, sir, I have no intention of making light of this committee. And I have no intention of incurring your wrath, Mr. Chairman. I have a few friends who have already incurred your wrath. They've sent me letters from jail.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Mr. Appleton?  Mr. Appleton?

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: I... I need a drink of water.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Go ahead, son.

turns.speaker: PETE
turns.text: Mr. Chairman... there's... another Amendment... that I'd like to invoke at this time, but it's not the Fifth Amendment.  I wonder if you're familiar with it.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Mr. Appleton, you will...

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Cecil!  Cecil, there's a young man in there...

turns.speaker: ELDRIDGE
turns.text: Lord love a duck, Harry, you wanna give me a heart attack right in front of the doctor's office?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Listen to me!  The young man in there...

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Only one in town.  Get in, son.

turns.speaker: ELDRIDGE
turns.text: Ben, when's Delly due back?

turns.speaker: ELDRIDGE
turns.text: Here we are.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Well, son, you're home!

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Thanks for the lift, Cecil.

turns.speaker: ELDRIDGE
turns.text: Don't mention it.  Welcome home, Luke.

turns.speaker: ELDRIDGE
turns.text: No wallet, huh?

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: No identification at all.  What're you thinkin', Cecil?

turns.speaker: ELDRIDGE
turns.text: What I'm thinkin' is we got us one a'two things here.  A mystery or a damn miracle.  And by god I can't tell which.  Boy, you say you have no idea who you are?  That right?

turns.speaker: ELDRIDGE
turns.text: Doc, with your permission, I want to bring someone in here.  Maybe it'll jar this young man's memory.

turns.speaker: LARDNER
turns.text: By all means.
